title: Birch Shrubs (Betula spp.)
name: birch shrubs
rationale: LightGBM provided the best quantitative performance.
description: The birch shrubs diagnostic species set consists of all Betula taxa that occur in Alaska and Yukon as shrubs: Betula nana ssp. exilis (Sukaczev) Hultén and Betula glandulosa Michx. These taxa frequently hybridize with each other and often cannot be clearly separated (Furlow 1997). Betula glandulosa also frequently hybridizes with Betula neoalaskana Sarg. to form a tall shrub birch hybrid, which has been referred to variously as Betula neoalaskana × glandulosa or Betula ×dugleana Lepage. Hultén (1968) listed the hybrid under Betula occidentalis, but the material from Alaska and Yukon does not match the original concept of Betula occidentalis. Given that we do not have a clear name to apply to the birch shrub hybrid in Alaska, we apply the temporary name Betula cf. occidentalis ined. We excluded Betula cf. occidentalis ined. from birch shrubs because it tends to grow in sporadic clusters, rather than the continuous cover often formed by Betula nana ssp. exilis and Betula glandulosa, and it often grows into a form intermediate between a tree and a shrub.
